title: Sociology: Recommended Grade Level: Grades 11 or 12
subject: Social Studies (2014-2020)

document.title: Indiana Department of Education College and Career Readiness

14F4A6EF073042BFAD8B626FC3551167.description: Explore theoretical foundations of punishment. (retributive, rehabilitative, deterrent)

C73CD64DEC7A4669AB76E81F863CC621.description: Identify the consequences of the medicalization of deviance

CAFA324264E24325AF60F2E091B34C13.description: Identify types of crime and its consequences

557AD7F6DB4B405C9010AD545BDCD0E0.description: Examine deviance from a conflict perspective

7D3F57B1A54746C98CFBF0314990AEC5.description: From a symbolic interaction analysis, examine labeling theory

66783CD0A514418DBCA3DF81D95DFE8F.description:
Explore explanations of deviance such as Merton’s Strain theory, Sutherland’s differential association theory, and
Hirschi’s control theory

43A72B749E414079B07EE7FF004EA347.description: Explore the functions deviance serves as identified by Emile Durkheim

6A99B78F2F8949F791589E70007C88FB.description: Identify formal and informal, as well as positive and negative forms of social control employed in our society

494523BC12204F40A6E6620D6E3B588B.description: Define deviance and analyze deviance from a functionalist, a conflict, and an interactionist perspective

1DEE37B24D3B4081A4C1D90CFC6C53A4.description: Investigate how incorrect communications, such as rumors or gossip, can influence group behavior

FF7977FC93FD482CA2B5074A04CCD180.description: Identify a community social problem and discuss appropriate actions to address the problem

3D7B4B814DDA40E5ABF6B9EBC5A8FA59.description:
Determine a cause-and-effect relationship among historical events, themes and concepts in United States and
world history as they relate to sociology

A9915E6ACC6141FF9BBE63305CD92644.description: Discuss both the benefits and social costs of collective behavior in society

CA2B9D047B5D4D7EA23D611AB6CC232A.description: Define propaganda and discuss the methods of propaganda used to influence social behavior

527BC47D8FC64C07B24A9EACFD4D16A2.description: Discuss the impact of leaders of different social movements

581857BAADDC4BB4BB0325AC6F65C173.description: Examine factors that could lead to the breakdown and disruption of an existing community

E4EEAECDCC884A7F96633BF8531E6B7F.description: Define a social issue to be analyzed

BADBC4755B4D4AA4B0418488FA617D2D.description: Discuss theories that attempt to explain collective behavior

F6B10C4CBB9C4C8282650933EDA7FD99.description:
Describe how collective behavior (working in groups) can influence and change society. Use historical and
contemporary examples to define collective behavior

A34A7A773464492B912E676FCBFE4A19.description: Describe traditions, roles and expectations necessary for a community to continue

8B307D765BAB4FA0A07A2064BCAE65AF.description:
Design and carry out school- and community-based projects to address a local aspect of a social problem.
(Economics)

9343B7D4EEEB448D8A4B007B7FBA4E1C.description:
Survey local agencies involved in addressing social problems to determine the extent of the problems in the local
community

55E96B13E4C241F9AA6A11AF75996B33.description:
Evaluate possible solutions to resolving social problems and the consequences that might result from those
solutions

18D5DD94D20E480A802910DC4ECB8B9B.description: Examine how individual and group responses are often associated with social problems

87A78326389B4C4BA78B850E72DD7FDE.description: Discuss the implications of social problems for society

0436550C77AD41F49701F7393BCF510A.description: Explain how patterns of behavior are found with certain social problems

7677A8550A834927BD721B33E0E236E0.description: Describe how social problems have changed over time (History)

9BF2B6EAE3AD4647AF9BEA911C5448DC.description: Identify characteristics of a “social” problem, as opposed to an “individual” problem

B82943FCB1494A32B724570F15E8AF52.description: Evaluate a current issue that has resulted from scientific discoveries and/or technological innovations

BD777497A0C54CE8A17A6D9D3F0DD6A7.description: Cite examples of the use of technology in social research

2A523EAF6702448EB0F129E47CF994B8.description: Trace the development of the use of a specific type of technology in the community

EEFF0512F5A44CDFAFE112844807CA6C.description: Investigate the consequences to society as a result of changes

6461A45339624C6DAEA0119BE8A091B5.description: Distinguish major differences between social movements and collective behavior with examples

DFABD3DAC1AE443E8739E6552CE58C32.description:
Describe how the role of the mass media has changed over time and project what changes might occur in the
future

F3D60AAE2170484A973500502725B60D.description: Discuss how innovations in science and technology affect social interaction and culture

1DD23099103F4D31A667B723FE951CC4.description: Examine how technological innovations and scientific discoveries have influenced major social institutions

C9FFB154435F42EA9F7F37A6B8F93236.description: Using an example, describe how collective behavior can influence and change society

057258BB8B8C4C6DB221DC4739A40A2B.description: Examine various social influences that can lead to immediate and long-term changes

2A367AA456F741C182C088B0A165309E.description: Describe how and why societies change over time

205805FA20BF407B999CAFD8601CEA06.description:
Examine in depth one or more important social institutions (such as marriage and family, education, health care,
judicial, health care, religion) and its functions for society. Also consider how conflict theory sees the institution

563338C28A614F84AB8DA1682AEF36CD.description: Conduct research and analysis on an issue associated with social structure or social institutions

6E360CD1C2BA44D19405E499D2FF1303.description: Discuss the concept of political power and factors that influence political power

178136590CEA483FA81EE2F687EF7AE4.description:
Identify basic social institutions and explain their impact on individuals, groups and organizations within society and
how they transmit the values of society

853BA9BA980041ADA5331FD4B9710806.description: Define social institution as made up of norms and values surrounding an activity considered important to society

7A750422FD7D496CA299023F467B76B6.description: Demonstrate democratic approaches to managing disagreements and solving conflicts

92070AC7A3DD46A4BE92CB231669D858.description: Explore the formation of group norms

E5A7077FF5374E8698C77895DDA2B9A3.description: Define different types of groups (involuntary, voluntary, coercive, reference)

96132A7943B0421F99E46D0C4211514B.description: Define ethnocentrism and explain how it can be beneficial or destructive to a culture

57292F2DE628493EB7419DABA67A3E35.description: Describe group leadership styles (authoritarian, democratic, laissez-faire) and the functions of each style

57237C4245904D45BCCAB45B5FB7FDCA.description:
Explain how the importance of primary and secondary groups have changed over time, particularly in relation to
 pre-industrial and industrial society

5ACFC953E442493BA06BDC940AC06EC8.description: Outline and illustrate the functions of groups both for individual group members and for society

B23562E9EB374B98AC291223BA18D4BF.description: Explore reasons for group formation; distinguish instrumental from expressive needs

5D240626E41840EAA52892CF416E61BE.description: Distinguish between primary groups and secondary groups with examples of each

EEAE7157557A48E79BFA36DE3B772664.description: Sociologically define social group and distinguish groups from crowds, aggregates, etc.

5896E9A3FEE842E6B709E063BD54CDE6.description: Examine gender roles from the functionalist, the interactionist, and the conflict perspectives

88A556586ABA42D9B982E96CE81270A6.description: Explore how gender roles differ in different societies and how they change over time

8F4665EBC1064B4397EF910B9DA1EA3D.description: Describe the functional explanation of gender role socialization and contrast it with the conflict explanation

6603469A7FC04F72959EF8CD6D31A320.description: Explore how gender role socialization occurs

A71153E9276F48E9B6D7CD1511A7BE3D.description: Distinguish between biological (ascribed) status and socially assigned gender roles

68FBD54E7B9A40E68D868DD758937742.description: Explain how roles and role expectations can lead to role conflict

9AC1B36403A6465BB3C001E0F9393E16.description: Distinguish between the terms role, status, and esteem

747367AB2AA24C1B9260CDCDC480F5D6.description:
Explore stratification and inequality in the United States including its causes and consequences; distinguish
 between inequality of opportunity and inequality of condition

C765312BA6E14B8A8A8F7B27E99EC879.description: Explore some of the consequences (or results) of stratification

754A8BF178C34D3BBF508ED07AF1EAFA.description: Explain how stratification differs from simple inequality and how stratification relates to ideology

9EE67FACDDBC4DCDB27B31CC1AF960CB.description:
Explore the origins of stratification in human societies from a functionalist perspective and from a conflict
 perspective

25266E0D144447D79DA9074EB263824C.description:
Identify how different types of societies compare regarding stratification. (i.e. competitive vs. noncompetitive,
 caste and class systems: ascribed vs. achieved status)

CE2CEA0B705F4EF9A2F685122F4F0F9F.description: Examine Weber’s multi-dimensional model of stratification and compare with Marx’s one dimensional model

BBEB08BF7C724A2A9461C4A304B272E3.description: Discuss how societies recognize rites of passage

CA216A00A8714043971EE3E39994CF50.description:
Identify the major agents of socialization and evaluate the role each plays (family, play group, peer group, school,
 mass media, job, religion, total institutions – re-socialization, and others)

746C596766A94150B648E0AE421FAEED.description:
Identify the goals of socialization (transmission of culture including values inculcation, self-control and social
 control, appropriate role behavior, skills attainment)

0CC9283B78B64BCEADD1557F2A8270E1.description:
Explore the contributions of George Herbert Mead and Charles Horton Cooley (as well as Freud and Piaget) to
 the development of theories of self concept

A270A52BFFE94D3AB4F1AF927442FED3.description:
Explain how human capacity for extensive symbolic communication allows for socialization and cultural
 transmission

9B7F9AD1D3D44D28B88EC835BC0944EE.description: Explain how the self concept is formed (from the interactionist perspective)

6523BDF1E5744EB0892BC50687A72039.description:
Define socialization as a process unique to humans that takes place from birth to death, and how it changes
 through the life cycle

8C71585B2AF34DD7992BCB33FEB8C34B.description: Explain how functionalists, interactionists, and conflict theorists differ in their view culture

269B1EFBE9374F2BB7ED5E94BF71D912.description: Identify both rights and responsibilities the individual has to the group

7B32FF9418CC467EA0F729192C0DCF71.description:
Prepare original written and oral reports and presentations on specific events, people or historical eras as related to
sociological research

1C3BCA5FEA2E40CC8FE134EED8FB35FC.description: Compare and contrast different types of societies, such as hunting and gathering, agrarian, industrial, and postindustrial

E347023C121342C78EA788B4AAE487F4.description: Define and explore the defining characteristics of subcultures in the United States

0FDCA6A951F2466DAB7225706463E9E6.description:
Explain the relationship between norms and values; explain how norms develop and change in a society;
distinguish between folkways and mores

45944A4C406B46F19B246755B02501BC.description: Identify culture conflict, cultural similarity, cultural diversity

A2BAE5D050E54998A066D4A12C518736.description: Identify American cultural values; explain how the U.S. is a heterogeneous society

FC8F7240C4634FB5B241379BA815E729.description: Identify and apply elements of nature vs. nurture in explaining human social behavior

26E54E091E9140CEA07EA4AFF5B2F604.description: Explain the differences between the concepts: culture and society

9310C6DEFFDE4CD5BDFBE5149BD0C7AF.description: Define culture as a human survival strategy; Identify the, material and non-material components of culture

96F10737114D40ABBFD7AFDB6719FFD3.description:
Prepare original written and oral reports and presentations on specific events, people or historical eras as related to
sociological research

3F58E9C2E9244139987673BB451F1649.description:
Develop a research design applying appropriate methodology, and use of the scientific method as it applies to
social scientific research; include the development of a hypothesis, data collection, data interpretation, and drawing
conclusions

4080FF198D9E4ADA97741E8B4BBB09E0.description: Distinguish fact from opinion in data sources to analyze various points of view about a social issue

64C1BE3696BD4FACB6F39AACE2E4A3E9.description:
Identify the research methods commonly used by sociologists including survey research, content/historical
 analysis, secondary analysis, laboratory method, observation, participant observation, case study. Explain the
 strengths and weaknesses of each

0C7B52A4BC884448806160472A278E12.description:
Describe how observations become generalizations which become theories through replication with the use of the
 scientific method

CB6A82195A1E49EDA4AF3FDAF06F71F5.description:
Illustrate the relationship of sociology to the other social science disciplines, including history, economics,
 psychology, political science

2BD32C8BBDF44C7480655926D51D5284.description: Identify key figures in the development of the discipline of sociology

4F40024AD8F04EC592B68212C3801DE8.description: Define sociology and trace its development as a distinct discipline

DF92B43E6E124421B903B75C8C7C22B1.description: Foundations of Sociology as a Social Science
